In these early times, the palliam was the distinc- tive mark of episcopal authority in full exercise. When

a Pope or patriarch was deposed, his pallium was taken from him. When Pope Felix IV. desired to invest his

successor before his own death, ha delivered up to him his pallium.⁹ It would seem that in the East, and also in countries following the Gallican use, the palliam was worn indiscriminately by all bishops, and it is im- possible to say whether or not they needed to be invested with it by their metropolitana cr patriarcha. The Roman custom of reserving this markos honour· for certain bishops only, and of sending it to them from Rome, appears to be a modification of the primitive institution. I am rather inclined to believe that it had some connection with the change of ideas and of language which transformed an official badge into a relic of the apostle Peter.

Although originally derived from the same source aa that of other bishops, the Pope's pallium acquired gradually a different and more exalted significance.
